content: The FY2003 omnibus appropriations act (P.L. 108-7, H.J.Res. 2) signed into law by the President includes $74.25 billion in funding for USDA and related agencies, with $17.545 billion for discretionary programs. An additional $3.1 billion is allocated for supplemental disaster assistance for farmers and ranchers affected by natural disasters in 2001 or 2002. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) operates through 30 internal agencies with 100,000 employees, and its FY2002 gross outlays were $79.95 billion, with food and nutrition programs accounting for 50% of spending. In FY2002, USDA spending totaled $79.95 billion, with 50% allocated to food and nutrition programs, including the food stamp program, child nutrition programs, and the Women, Infants and Children (WIC) program. The second largest spending area was for farm and foreign agricultural services, totaling $22.9 billion. Additionally, $7.0 billion was allocated for natural resource and environment programs, with a focus on the Forest Service. Rural development programs received $2.72 billion in gross outlays for FY2002. USDA spending in FY2002 totaled $79.95 billion, with key areas including food and nutrition programs, farm and foreign agricultural services, natural resource and environment programs, and rural development. Approximately three-fourths of USDA spending is classified as mandatory, with programs like farm commodity support, food stamps, crop insurance, and agricultural conservation receiving funding. The USDA budget in FY2002 totaled $79.95 billion, with three-fourths classified as mandatory spending. This includes funding for food stamp and child nutrition programs, commodity support programs, and other mandatory programs. The remaining 25% is for discretionary programs like Forest Service programs, rural development programs, and food inspection programs, funded through annual appropriations acts. The USDA budget in FY2002 totaled $79.95 billion, with three-fourths classified as mandatory spending for food stamp and child nutrition programs, commodity support programs, and other mandatory programs. The remaining 25% is for discretionary programs like Forest Service programs, rural development programs, and food inspection programs, funded through annual appropriations acts. Funding for USDA discretionary programs is provided by the annual agriculture appropriations act, while Forest Service programs are included in the annual Interior appropriations act. Congress controls spending on mandatory programs by setting rules for eligibility and benefit formulas, while discretionary programs are controlled by annual appropriations. The Bush Administration released its budget request for FY2003, requesting $74.062 billion for the U.S. Department of Agriculture and related agencies. This amount is $814 million above the FY2002 enacted appropriation. The FY2002 enacted level includes supplemental appropriations in response to the September 11, 2001 attacks. The Bush Administration requested nearly $500 million in supplemental appropriations for USDA, FDA, and CFTC in response to the September 11, 2001 attacks. The requested $17.421 billion for discretionary accounts was $1.145 billion above the FY2002 appropriation. The 107th Congress adjourned without passing the appropriations bill, and the 108th Congress considered it as part of an omnibus bill. The House Appropriations Committee completed markups of the FY2003 agriculture bill for USDA and related agencies. The total appropriations in the bill were $74.306 billion, with $17.601 billion for discretionary programs and $56.705 billion for mandatory USDA programs. The discretionary level in the House bill was $1.325 billion higher than the regular FY2002 appropriations. The full House adopted a continuing resolution to finalize funding decisions on remaining regular appropriations. The House adopted a continuing resolution (H.J.Res. 2) in early January 2003 to finalize funding decisions on remaining regular appropriations bills, including agriculture. The Senate-amended version of H.J.Res. 2 was an omnibus appropriations measure that included the full-text of each outstanding regular bill. Prior to H.J.Res. 2, FY2003 spending for USDA and related agencies was governed by eight continuing resolutions. The Senate Appropriations Committee reported its version of the FY2003 agriculture appropriations bill (S. 2801) with total funding of $74.66 billion, $354 million above the House bill. The Senate combined the FY2003 agriculture appropriations bill with other bills into an omnibus package, which was adopted as an amendment to H.J.Res. 2. Funding levels for USDA in H.J.Res. 2 were similar to S. 2801, with additional funds for farm assistance and emergency famine relief in Africa. The FY2003 omnibus appropriations bill (H.J.Res. 2) included $3.1 billion in farm assistance, $500 million for emergency famine relief in Africa, and an across-the-board reduction in discretionary programs. The bill was signed into law as P.L. 108-7 on February 20, 2003, combining 11 appropriations bills from the previous Congress. The total budget authority for USDA and related agencies was $74.25 billion, with $17.55 billion for discretionary programs and $56.70 billion for mandatory programs. The FY2003 omnibus appropriations bill (P.L. 108-7) included $3.1 billion in farm assistance and an across-the-board reduction in discretionary programs. The discretionary appropriation was $56 million below the House-reported level and $805 million below the Senate-passed level. The total budget authority for USDA and related agencies was $74.25 billion, with $17.55 billion for discretionary programs and $56.70 billion for mandatory programs. The FY2003 omnibus appropriations bill (P.L. 108-7) included funding for various mission areas and agencies within USDA, as well as for the Food and Drug Administration. Most spending for USDA's mandatory agriculture and conservation programs is funded through the Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC), which has the legal authority to borrow funds from the U.S. Treasury. This report will continue to track congressional action on FY2003 agriculture appropriations. The Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) funds ongoing farm programs, emergency spending, and disaster payments. It must repay borrowed funds but relies on congressional appropriations to replenish losses and maintain borrowing authority. The CCC receives an indefinite appropriation due to difficulty in estimating funding needs. The CCC has received an indefinite appropriation in recent years to cover losses from crop and weather conditions. In FY2000, net outlays totaled $32 billion, exceeding the $30 billion borrowing limit. The Administration requested $16.285 billion for FY2003, with an additional $3.1 billion for farm disaster assistance. This was approved in the omnibus appropriations act (P.L. 108-7) due to severe drought conditions. The omnibus appropriations act (P.L.108-7) provides $3.1 billion in economic and disaster assistance for agricultural producers affected by severe drought in 2001 and 2002. The assistance is funded by a spending limitation on the Conservation Security Program over the next 10 years. The Administration did not request assistance and insisted on offsetting any aid with reductions in other farm spending. Major provisions include crop disaster assistance with a payment formula similar to the one used in 2000. The Commodity Credit Corporation will fully fund a disaster payment formula similar to the one used for ad-hoc 2000 crop disaster payments. Eligible producers can receive a payment equal to 50% of the relevant price for crop losses exceeding 35% in 2001 or 2002. Producers who waived insurance will receive 45% of the price. Sugar and tobacco have separate disaster payment programs. Producers must choose between a 2001 or 2002 payment, not both. The total disaster payment, crop insurance, and crop value cannot exceed 95% of the crop value. Participants must purchase crop insurance for the next two crop years. The Livestock Assistance Program under P.L. 108-7 provides $250 million for compensating livestock forage or feed losses due to natural disasters in 2001 or 2002. Producers in disaster-declared counties can choose between 2001 or 2002 losses and are eligible for the Livestock Compensation Program without date restrictions. The program is estimated to cost $100 million and is funded through Section 32 funds traditionally used for surplus commodity purchases. The LCP provision under P.L. 108-7 costs $100 million and is funded through Section 32 funds. The omnibus act requires new spending to come from the Commodity Credit Corporation and reimburses Section 32 with $250 million in CCC funds. Other assistance includes disaster payments to sugar beet producers, payments to sugarcane producers for hurricane losses, compensation for tobacco producers, and funds for Florida citrus growers affected by citrus canker. The federal crop insurance program is administered by USDA's Risk Management Agency, offering free catastrophic insurance with the option to purchase additional coverage at a subsidized rate. The federal crop insurance program offers producers the opportunity to purchase additional insurance coverage at a subsidized rate through approved private insurance companies. The program is funded through appropriations, with discretionary funding for RMA salaries and expenses and necessary funding for the Federal Crop Insurance Fund. The FY2003 appropriation for RMA salaries and expenses is $70.708 million, slightly below the House-reported level. The FY2003 appropriation for RMA salaries and expenses is $70.708 million, slightly below the House-reported level. The Administration request for the crop insurance program is $72.771 million, with mandatory expenses estimated at $2.89 billion for FY2003. The FY2003 appropriation for the crop insurance program is virtually equal to the FY2002 estimate. Annual spending on the program is difficult to predict due to weather and crop conditions. Legislative enhancements in 2000 have contributed to significant improvements in the program. The crop insurance program saw legislative enhancements in 2000, leading to higher farmer participation. The FY2003 budget proposed limiting private insurance companies' underwriting gains to 11.5% of retained premiums, but no legislative action has been taken yet. The Senate directed USDA to follow current procedures before making any risk-sharing changes. The Commodity Credit Corporation funds farm income support and disaster assistance programs, with USDA overseeing program administration. Credit Corporation serves as the funding mechanism for farm income support and disaster assistance programs, with administration handled by USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA). FSA also manages commodity support programs, farm loan programs, conservation programs, and food assistance programs. The FY2003 omnibus appropriations act provides $976.7 million for FSA salaries and expenses, with an additional $70 million authorized from the Commodity Credit Corporation for farm disaster implementation costs. The FY2003 omnibus appropriations act provides $976.7 million for FSA salaries and expenses, with an additional $70 million authorized from the Commodity Credit Corporation for farm disaster implementation costs. The requested increase in funding is mainly due to increased pay costs and lack of carryover funds from the previous year. The funding level for FY2003 does not include any new activities associated with the 2002 farm bill. The 2002 farm bill (P.L. 107-171) provides $50 million in new mandatory funding for FSA salaries and expenses. FSA farm loan programs serve as a lender of last resort for family farmers, offering direct loans and guarantees for timely repayment. Some loans have subsidized interest rates, with an annual appropriation made to cover federal loan costs. The omnibus appropriations act (P.L. 108-7) provides $228.3 million to subsidize direct and guaranteed farm loans of $3.937 billion for FY2003. This funding level allows FSA to offer nearly double the amount of direct operating loans compared to FY2002. Supplemental funding has been provided in recent years for federal farm loans in response to low farm commodity prices, limiting farmers' ability to secure commercial farm loans. USDA's agricultural trade and food aid activities include programs funded by appropriations and borrowing authority of the CCC. The FY2003 omnibus appropriations act (P.L. 108-7) mainly addresses programs requiring appropriations, while CCC-funded activities are primarily addressed in budget proposals. The program level for USDA's international activities was about $6.1 billion for FY2003, reflecting increased spending for food aid. The program level for USDA's international activities was estimated at about $5.5 billion in FY2002, with increased spending for food aid. The Foreign Agricultural Service (FAS) administers USDA's international programs, including P.L. 480 Food for Peace. P.L. 108-7 provides $129.9 million for FAS salaries and expenses, slightly less than requested. P.L. 480 food aid accounts for $1.343 billion out of an appropriation. The enacted amount for USDA's international activities in FY2002 was about $5.5 billion, with increased spending on food aid. P.L. 108-7 provides $1.477 billion for discretionary agricultural trade programs, with $1.2 billion authorized for humanitarian commodity donations under P.L. 480 Title II. An additional $250 million was allocated for emergency relief activities under P.L. 480. Total appropriated international programs increased by $344 million from FY2002, mainly for humanitarian food donations in response to urgent food needs. The Administration's decision to phase out food aid based on commodity surpluses has led to an increase in food aid appropriations in response to urgent global food needs. Proposed reductions in surplus commodity programs are recommended, with a shift towards private voluntary organizations for food aid distribution. The FY2003 budget proposes an increase in P.L. 480 Title II commodity donations to offset the phase-out of certain programs. The Administration recommended increasing P.L. 480 Title II commodity donations in the FY2003 budget to compensate for the phase-out of Section 416(b) donations. Initial proposals excluded CCC funding for Food for Progress (FFP), which provides commodities to developing countries. The FFP program was reauthorized in the 2002 farm bill, complicating efforts to phase out CCC-funded food aid programs. P.L. 108-7 amended the FFP statute, requiring a minimum volume of commodities and agreements with various organizations. The President's FY2003 estimates include $158 million of CCC funding for Food for Progress (FFP) agreements with various organizations. The use of commodity surpluses for U.S. food aid has been criticized by trading partners for circumventing WTO export subsidy reduction commitments. The budget assumes $118 million for Section 416(b) programming in FY2003, mainly surplus nonfat dry milk. In FY2003, $118 million will be available for programming under Section 416(b), consisting mainly of surplus nonfat dry milk. Additionally, USDA international programs funded through CCC borrowing authority include $4.225 billion for export credit guarantees. U.S. export credit programs have been a topic of discussion in WTO agricultural trade negotiations. The EU and other trading partners criticize the U.S. export credit programs for giving unfair advantages in exporting agricultural commodities. Negotiations in the OECD were unsuccessful, and changes to the programs face strong congressional support. CCC-funded programs like MAP and FMDP aim to develop overseas markets for U.S. agricultural products. Spending for these programs is authorized in the 2002 farm bill. The EEP program has a spending limit of $28 million, reduced from the authorized level in the farm bill. The Export Enhancement Program (EEP) spending is limited to $28 million, resulting in savings of $450 million from the authorized level in the farm bill. The Dairy Export Incentive Program (DEIP) is expected to receive $57 million, and the McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program (IFED) has $100 million allocated for FY2002, with additional funding in subsequent years. The McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program (IFED) received $100 million for FY2002 and additional funding in subsequent fiscal years. The program began as a pilot project during the Clinton Administration and is financed by CCC funds. The Administration plans to expend $100 million on IFED in FY2003. For more information on agricultural trade and food aid, refer to CRS Issue Briefs IB98006 and IB10077.
